title: [other] add links to other style guides
body:
Share our other open source style guides.

@ljharb @justjake @mikefowler @jasonkb

title: generate test cases from our styleguide's README.md
body:
WORK IN PROGRESS
1. get all the code blocks from the styleguide README.md
2. split out examples based on `// bad`, `// good`, `// best` comments
3. prepend common setup code that occurs before each delimiters to each
   example
4. test each example:
   - all examples must be valid Javascript code according to ESLint using
     our config.
   - good examples must lint without errors or warnings
   - best examples must lint without errors or warnings
   - bad examples must fail linting

In the next commits, I plan to edit README.md to reduce the number of examples with irregular delimiters  like `// good - bla bla bla bla bla`

title: Modularize eslintrc, add tests
body:
- modularize eslint-config-airbnb a little bit: 
  - `eslint-config-airbnb/base` gives a react-free version
  - `eslint-config-airbnb` still gives the react-loaded version
- add tests to eslint-config-airbnb
  - validate that the React order rule config works
  - validate that `eslint-config-airbnb/base` does not depend on React plugin

I would consider making `eslint-config-airbnb/base` the default export, and making `eslint-config-airbnb/react` contain the react rules.

Let me know what you think.

/cc @ljharb @hshoff

title: Recommend exporting `propTypes` as a named export
body:
By exporting `propTypes` as a named export _as well_ as attaching them to the "class", they can be explicitly imported by tests and other components in a way that aligns with the future ES6 module dependency graph, rather than as an arbitrary property that isn't statically verifiable. Doing both is great imo.

Thoughts?

title: [React] Fixed Incorrect Class Declaration in Section 10
body: In the bad example for Section 10, the class that was defined was using half ES5 syntax and half ES6 syntax. That means there was a 100% of it producing a syntax error. I fixed it.

title: Implicit return + single expression
body:
Fixes #438.

I’ve upgraded the note about argument parens to a new rule – it reads better this way.

title: Add ComparaOnline to 'In The Wild' List
body: We are trying to keep some order here at [ComparaOnline](http://www.comparaonline.cl/) :)

title: Update README.md
body: deleted unnecessary whitespace after property key

title: Updated 25.1 to include a case with a lookup that has a hyphen in the classname
body:
I updated [Section 25.1](https://github.com/chrisngobanh/javascript#25.1) to include a case with a lookup that has a hyphen in the classname.
The naming convention that I have chosen for this is camelCase.

I felt that this is necessary because it isn't obvious what to do in this case.

Addresses #466

title: Add state to sort-comp rule before render
Simplify ESLint config package.
body:
This patch moves `.eslintrc` contents into `index.js` directly.
This allows us to drop external dependencies and using javascript
comments instead of not valid JSON.

title: Put `everything-else` before `render`
body:
When there is a custom method which is neither a handler nor a getter, put it between the two groups so that it doesn't end up after the `render` method.

This behavior is closer to the [default](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/blob/master/docs/rules/sort-comp.md#rule-options).

title: Change Maxparams
body: Why 7 ? Because it's a magic number.

title: Amendments section to encourage forking
body: Amendments alter what the style guide says but can be contained in a single section thus allowing you to periodically update or cherry pick from the style guide from master without having to deal with annoying merge conflicts.

title: use 120 max-len
body:
# Brief

The max-len rule of 80 columns is causing us to write less performant and harder to read code for an arbitrary goal.  This PR shows our code will be faster, easier to read, and easier to write by adopting a more modern wider max column length.
## Why 80 columns?

First, where did this standard come from and why was it used?
#### Punchcards

Yes, columns of 80 characters were instituted for IBM [punch cards](http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/148677/why-is-80-characters-the-standard-limit-for-code-width).  Somewhat arbitrarily as because they were wanted to reuse currency carriers [from 1890](http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/148677/why-is-80-characters-the-standard-limit-for-code-width/148678#comment-281684).
#### Old Tech

Typewriters, early text editors, and early terminals also used this _traditional_ width as seen [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Characters_per_line).  All modern text editors and terminals now support variable column widths (and softwrap if you prefer).  Even so, the StackOverflow 2015 survey [shows ~82%](http://stackoverflow.com/research/developer-survey-2015#tech-editor) of developers do not use a terminal as their text editor.

> Side note, JS is the [most popular](http://stackoverflow.com/research/developer-survey-2015#tech-lang) tech :D Woooo!
#### Readability

It is widely regarded that columns ~40-66-ish are most readable.  So, "narrower columns are more readable than wider columns". Science has shown this to be false.  On screen columns narrower than 95cpl actually decrease reading [speed and comprehension](http://psychology.wichita.edu/surl/usabilitynews/72/pdf/Usability%20News%2072%20-%20Shaikh.pdf).  Summary [here](http://viget.com/inspire/the-line-length-misconception).
## Why _not_ 80 columns

Here are some pragmatic reasons why we should _not_ be using this antiquated arbitrary standard.
### Code Performance
#### Variables & Closures

In order to fit code into narrower columns, variables that would _not otherwise be initialized_ are often initialized just to break down column count.  This is unjustified as it is not for readability, performance, or organization.

Declaring and initializing variables costs cycles and memory.  More importantly, it encourages [closure abuse](https://developers.google.com/speed/articles/optimizing-javascript#avoiding-pitfalls-with-closures) because the developer is likely to move code in a nested location up to an outer closure to gain the extra indentation, allowing it to fit on a single line.
#### Concatenating strings

Strings are often forced to be concatenated when arbitrarily limiting column width.  This causes extra code, extra operations, and decreased readability.  Concatenating strings is a known [performance issue](https://developers.google.com/speed/articles/optimizing-javascript#working-with-strings).  Using a `[].join('')` is faster but also unnecessarily slow and verbose when the entire issue can be circumvented by allowing a string to be defined in a single line.
### Developer Performance
#### Problem Solving Energy

The developer is no longer just thinking "how do I write elegant code?" but also now adds the constraint "how I do refactor my elegant code to fit inside 80 columns?"  These are extra brain cycles that could be put toward solving application engineering problems instead of arbitrarily fitting their code into 80 columns.
#### Code Reasoning

Breaking code down into such small segments can turn an easily turn a readable 2/3 LOC into a very contrived set of variables and string concatenations that is difficult to parse.  In my experience, this outcome is more common than an improved outcome when limiting lines to 80 columns.

It is also harder to retain your train of thought about the system when you have to stop and reason about the superfluous variables and concatenation for an individual method before moving on.
#### Comprehension

The developer regularly has to ask "what words can I cut out of this to make it fit".  The result is often a hasty move to hack and slash a less helpful error message, a more cryptic method name, further abbreviated variables, etc.
#### Diversion

Really stop and think about how many times a day you fiddle with a line, 2, 3, 4 times trying various refactors because you are 1-4 characters over the limit.  These changes were not prompted to improve user experience, developer efficiency, nor system performance but to meet an arbitrary goal with no tangible benefits.  Seems tiny, but this stuff adds up.  Like how recaptcha accidentally wasted a [>a quarter billion](http://www.cnet.com/news/recaptcha-reusing-your-wasted-time-online/) hours of human energy a year.
## Why 120 columns?

Breaking things down can be good.  Breaking them down too much can be bad.  The PR suggests 120 columns (another arbitrary standard) still requires the developer to break down code, but with far less negative impact to code performance, developer performance, and readability.
# Conclusion

The 'standard' 80 column width is arbitrary and antiquated.  There is no measurable gain to the user, the developer, nor the system by limiting columns.  Further, it is shown above that this limit actually decrease code performance, developer performance, and readability.  A wider arbitrary limit reduces these negative impacts while maintaining the sometimes helpful rule to break code down.

:facepunch:

title: Add missing `state`
body: There's `defaultProps` but there's no `state` for React.

title: Mention eslint-config-airbnb
body:
Actually, if we want to make the thing more convenient, we could go as far as saying:

``````
Before using our `.eslintrc` install these dependencies:

```sh
npm install --save-dev eslint-config-airbnb eslint babel-eslint eslint-plugin-react
```
``````

I want to leave the decision up to you though.
